name: 4-nitrobiphenyl
source: Beilstein F. K.; Beilsteins Handbuch der Organischen Chemie. Springer; Berlin; 1972.

name: 4-nitrobiphenyl
source: Beilstein F. K.; Beilsteins Handbuch der Organischen Chemie. Springer; Berlin; 1972.
Reason: The target compound 4-nitrobiphenyl consists of two benzene rings linked together (biphenyl structure), and a nitro group is attached to the fourth position on one of the rings. The basic unit here is biphenyl, which has a melting point around 69°C due to its planar structure and strong intermolecular π-π stacking interactions. The introduction of a nitro group to the benzene ring will have a significant impact on the melting point due to the following reasons: The nitro group is electron-withdrawing, which enhances the polarity of the molecule and increases intermolecular forces such as dipole-dipole interactions. This should increase the melting point. Moreover, the nitro group's ability to form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds with other molecules is limited due to the position and lack of suitable hydrogen bond donors or acceptors. Therefore, its effect on the melting point will primarily be through the introduction of polarity. Adding a nitro group to a benzene ring typically raises the melting point by approximately 45°C, due to the increased intermolecular forces. The two fused benzene rings provide additional rigidity and planarity to the molecular structure, enhancing the π-π stacking, and this can also add to the melting point, which we can estimate as a 20°C increase over a single benzene ring. Thus, the prediction is calculated by adding these effects to the base melting point of biphenyl.
Prediction: 69 (base biphenyl) + 45 (nitro group effect) + 20 (extra rigidity from biphenyl structure) = 134°C

name: 4-nitrobiphenyl
source: Beilstein F. K.; Beilsteins Handbuch der Organischen Chemie. Springer; Berlin; 1972.
Reason: The target compound 4-nitrobiphenyl includes a biphenyl structure with a nitro group attached to it. The base unit, biphenyl, with two benzene rings, has a melting point around 69°C which is due to its ability to engage in strong π-π stacking interactions between the flat aromatic systems. The introduction of a nitro group generally increases the melting point due to its electron-withdrawing nature that enhances the polarity of the molecule. It can also introduce some steric bulk. Typically, the addition of a nitro group to a benzene ring can increase the melting point significantly; however, the ability to form hydrogen bonds in this case is not relevant due to the geometry and lack of hydrogen bond donating groups. In similar molecules, this addition has been observed to raise the melting point by around 30-40°C. The rigidity and symmetry of the biphenyl system itself can also enhance the crystallinity and increase the melting point. The increased planarity and rigidity due to the biphenyl structure would add approximately 15°C to the base benzene structure. Considering these factors, I'll adjust the predictive influence of the nitro group downwards slightly from the previously considered 45°C to a more commensurate 35°C to better align with the melting point adjustments seen in similar structures.
Prediction: 69 (base biphenyl) + 35 (nitro group effect) + 15 (extra rigidity from biphenyl structure) = 119°C
